Queen Elizabeth officially opened a new science center in Glasgow earlier this month at Pacific Quay, an area of reclaimed docklands in the heart of the city. The Glasgow Science Center is housed in three buildings, the Glasgow Tower, the Science Mall and the IMAX Theater.

The tower, 417 feet high, revolves 360 degrees. At the base are galleries that showcase the city's past and possible future development with an emphasis on the role of science and technology. An elevator takes visitors to a platform at 335 feet, where there are 20-mile views in all directions.

The IMAX Theater is currently showing three films: ''Mysteries of Egypt,'' with Omar Sharif as a wise grandfather; ''Thrill Ride,'' from the first roller coasters to sophisticated virtual-reality rides; and ''Dolphins,'' a study of dolphin communication and behavior.

The Science Mall, the crescent-shaped main building, has four floors of interactive exhibits; themes include exploration and discovery, engineering, communication and digital design. Environmental issues like climate change and energy
use are explored with solar sunflowers and wind-powered generators. An area called the Clyde Explorer focuses on
rivers, with exhibits including a tide
gauge and an adjustable map showing how global warming and higher water levels may affect the area. The building also houses a planetarium and a virtual reality theater.

Glasgow Science Center, 50 Pacific Quay, (44-141) 420-5000, www.gsc.org.uk, is open daily; admission to the Science Mall is $9, children $6.30. The Tower and IMAX are each $7.75 additional for adults, $5.65 for children. Combination tickets for two or all three attractions are available.
